description: From Latin distinctus, perfect passive participle of distinguere (“to push apart, to divide”), + -ive (forming adjectives signifying relation or tendency to). Cognate with French distinctif and Medieval Latin distinctivus.

adjectives.description: distinctive (comparative more distinctive, superlative most distinctive)

entries.meaning: Distinguishing, used to or enabling the distinguishing of some thing.
(rare) Discriminating, discerning, having the ability to distinguish between things.
(rare) Distinguished, being distinct in character or position.
examples: The refugees... at length ceased to exist as a distinctive body among the people.

entries.meaning: (Hebrew grammar, of accents) Used to separate clauses in place of stops.
examples: These are the main distinctive accents, and by stopping at them... the reader will do justice to the sense.

entries.meaning: (linguistics, of sounds) Distinguishing a particular sense of word.
examples: Normally we symbolize only phonemes (distinctive features) so far as we can determine them.

entries.meaning: A distinctive thing: a quality or property permitting distinguishing; a characteristic.
examples: ...the red umbrella, the distinctive of royalty here...
A distinctive of less power than Zakeph is Ṭiphḥâ.

entries.meaning: (theology) A distinctive belief, tenet, or dogma of a denomination or sect.
examples: Mennonites could go forth somewhat detached from the chauvinism of Western culture—but not so from the Mennonite distinctives.
